Leon S. Kennedy: We need to work together, Ada. There's too much at stake this time.
Ada Wong: Isn't that what you said last time? And look how that turned out.

Leon S. Kennedy: I know. But we've learned from our mistakes, haven’t we? This is different.
Ada Wong: Different? Or just the same old song with different lyrics?

Leon S. Kennedy: You’re always so cryptic. We can't afford doubt now. We need a plan.
Ada Wong: Plans are just illusions. Ever hear of adaptability, Leon? It's about seizing the moment.

Leon S. Kennedy: Adaptability is great, but we need a solid framework to operate. Too much chaos and we’ll lose everything.
Ada Wong: And what do you propose? That we maneuver through this labyrinth on blind faith?

Leon S. Kennedy: No, I’m suggesting we lean on each other’s strengths. You’ve got your resources and information; I’ve got... well, I can handle the combat.
Ada Wong: Ah, the classic divide—strength and intellect. But what happens when intellect fails in the heat of battle?

Leon S. Kennedy: Then we rely on our instincts. You know that better than anyone. You’ve done it before.
Ada Wong: Instincts won't save you when surrounded, Leon. Sometimes it takes more than just a trigger finger.

Leon S. Kennedy: I’m not just about pulling the trigger. I’m here to keep people safe, and that includes you.
Ada Wong: Safety is a mirage in our world. Always remember, my safety comes second to my goals.

Leon S. Kennedy: You’re always so focused on the end game, Ada. Doesn’t anyone else matter to you?
Ada Wong: Everyone matters, Leon. But I choose my battles wisely; attachments cloud judgment.

Leon S. Kennedy: So you just plan to leave again once this is over?
Ada Wong: Plans have a way of changing. You should know that better than anyone.

Leon S. Kennedy: I’ve always been willing to fight for what’s right. For you, that fight comes with confusion.
Ada Wong: Confusion is a product of predictability. I intrigue you, don’t I? Keeps you on your toes.

Leon S. Kennedy: Intrigued, yes. Confused? Definitely. I’m trying to find a way to trust you.
Ada Wong: Trust is a dangerous word, Leon. Perhaps it’s better to work towards a common goal rather than banking on trust.

Leon S. Kennedy: But I have to trust you at some level. This partnership relies on it, doesn’t it?
Ada Wong: A partnership, yes. Trust? That’s a two-way street. Just don’t expect a proper map.

Leon S. Kennedy: Then we make our own map, one step at a time. I’m willing to try if you are.
Ada Wong: A tentative truce, then. But remember, Leon, clarity often comes from chaos.

Leon S. Kennedy: Just don’t disappear on me again when it gets messy. We face this together.
Ada Wong: Who knows, Leon? I might surprise you. Sometimes I enjoy the mess.

Leon S. Kennedy: As long as I know you’re with me, I can handle any mess. Just say the word.
Ada Wong: Then let’s see if you can keep up. I don’t wait for anyone, after all.

Leon S. Kennedy: You keep pushing me, and I’ll show you I can keep pace. Just don’t get lost in your shadows, Ada.
Ada Wong: And you just focus on the light. It’s much safer there, or is it? The unknown has its allure.
